articles.author: by
articles.description:
Do you find yourself designing screens with only a vague idea of how the things on the screen relate to the things elsewhere in the system? Do you leave stakeholder meetings with unclear directives that often seem to contradict previous conversations? You know a better understanding of user needs would help the team get clear on what you are actually trying to accomplish, but time and budget for research is tight. When it comes to asking for more direct contact with your users, you might feel like poor Oliver Twist, timidly asking, “Please, sir, I want some more.” 
Here’s the trick. You need to get stakeholders themselves to identify high-risk assumptions and hidden complexity, so that they become just as motivated as you to get answers from users. Basically, you need to make them think it…
articles.title: How to Sell UX Research with Two Simple Questions

articles.author: by
articles.description:
Do you remember when having a great website was enough? Now, people are getting answers from Siri, Google search snippets, and mobile apps, not just our websites. Forward-thinking organizations have adopted an omnichannel content strategy, whose mission is to reach audiences across multiple digital channels and platforms.
But how do you set up a content management system (CMS) to reach your audience now and in the future? I learned the hard way that creating a content model—a definition of content types, attributes, and relationships that let people and systems understand content—with my more familiar design-system thinking would capsize my customer’s omnichannel content strategy. You can avoid that outcome by creating content models that are semantic and that also connect related content.…
articles.title: A Content Model Is Not a Design System

articles.author: by
articles.description:
Antiracist economist Kim Crayton says that “intention without strategy is chaos.” We’ve discussed how our biases, assumptions, and inattention toward marginalized and vulnerable groups lead to dangerous and unethical tech—but what, specifically, do we need to do to fix it? The intention to make our tech safer is not enough; we need a strategy.
This chapter will equip you with that plan of action. It covers how to integrate safety principles into your design work in order to create tech that’s safe, how to convince your stakeholders that this work is necessary, and how to respond to the critique that what we actually need is more diversity. (Spoiler: we do, but diversity alone is not the antidote to fixing unethical, unsafe tech.)
The process for inclusive safety
When you are designing for …
articles.title: Design for Safety, An Excerpt

articles.title: Is the Great Neutrino Puzzle Pointing to Multiple Missing Particles?

articles.author: Pradeep Mutalik
articles.description:
The transcendental number π is as familiar as it is ubiquitous, but how does Euler’s number e transcend the ordinary?             
The post Where Transcendental Numbers Hide in Everyday Math first appeared on Quanta Magazine
articles.title: Where Transcendental Numbers Hide in Everyday Math

articles.author: Kevin Hartnett
articles.description:
Watanabe invented a new way of distinguishing shapes on his way to solving the last open case of the Smale conjecture, a central question in topology about symmetries of the sphere.            
The post How Tadayuki Watanabe Disproved a Major Conjecture About Spheres first appeared on Quanta Magazine
articles.title: How Tadayuki Watanabe Disproved a Major Conjecture About Spheres

articles.author: Katie McCormick
articles.description:
Time was found to flow differently between the top and bottom of a single cloud of atoms. Physicists hope that such a system will one day help them combine quantum mechanics and Einstein’s theory of gravity.            
The post An Ultra-Precise Clock Shows How to Link the Quantum World With Gravity first appeared on Quanta Magazine
articles.title: An Ultra-Precise Clock Shows How to Link the Quantum World With Gravity

articles.author: Jordana Cepelewicz
articles.description:
Scientists thought that the brain’s hearing centers might just process speech along with other sounds. But new work suggests that speech gets some special treatment very early on.            
The post The Brain Processes Speech in Parallel With Other Sounds first appeared on Quanta Magazine
articles.title: The Brain Processes Speech in Parallel With Other Sounds

articles.author: Robbert Dijkgraaf
articles.description:
Today’s powerful but little-understood artificial intelligence breakthroughs echo past examples of unexpected scientific progress.             
The post The Uselessness of Useful Knowledge first appeared on Quanta Magazine
articles.title: The Uselessness of Useful Knowledge

articles.author: Jonathan O'Callaghan
articles.description:
After a search of neutron stars finds preliminary evidence for hypothetical dark matter particles called axions, astrophysicists are devising new ways to spot them.            
The post A Hint of Dark Matter Sends Physicists Looking to the Skies first appeared on Quanta Magazine
articles.title: A Hint of Dark Matter Sends Physicists Looking to the Skies

articles.author: Allison Whitten
articles.description:
A new model of learning centers on bursts of neural activity that act as teaching signals — approximating backpropagation, the algorithm behind learning in AI.            
The post Neuron Bursts Can Mimic Famous AI Learning Strategy first appeared on Quanta Magazine
articles.title: Neuron Bursts Can Mimic Famous AI Learning Strategy

articles.author: Jordana Cepelewicz
articles.description:
When animals move through 3D spaces, the neat system of grid cell activity they use for navigating on flat surfaces gets more disorderly. That has implications for some ideas about memory and other processes.            
The post How Animals Map 3D Spaces Surprises Brain Researchers first appeared on Quanta Magazine
articles.title: How Animals Map 3D Spaces Surprises Brain Researchers

articles.author: Alexander Hellemans
articles.description:
Built upon the ubiquitous Fourier transform, the mathematical tools known as wavelets allow unprecedented analysis and understanding of continuous signals.

articles.title: How Wavelets Allow Researchers to Transform, and Understand, Data

articles.author: Thomas Lewton
articles.description:

articles.author: Anil Ananthaswamy
articles.description:

articles.title: A New Link to an Old Model Could Crack the Mystery of Deep Learning

articles.title: Mathematicians Prove Melting Ice Stays Smooth
